About Me

Background

I am a PhD student in Computer Science at the University of Cambridge, working under the supervision of Prof. Amanda Prorok in the Prorok Lab. My research is at the forefront of multi-agent systems, with a particular focus on developing intelligent coordination strategies for heterogeneous robot teams.

Prior to my PhD, I completed my Master's degree in Engineering with a specialization in optimization and network design. This background in mathematical optimization has strongly influenced my approach to multi-agent problems, leading me to develop principled solutions that balance theoretical rigor with practical applicability.

Research Interests

My research sits at the intersection of several exciting areas in AI and robotics:

  • Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems: Developing algorithms that enable diverse agents with different capabilities to work together effectively
  • Graph Neural Networks: Leveraging the power of graph-based representations for multi-agent communication and coordination
  • Reinforcement Learning: Creating novel RL algorithms tailored for multi-agent scenarios
  • Robotics Applications: Applying theoretical advances to real-world robotic systems
  • Simulation and Benchmarking: Building tools that accelerate research in multi-agent systems

Philosophy

I believe that the future of AI lies in systems that can collaborate, adapt, and learn from each other. My work is driven by the vision of creating intelligent agent teams that can tackle complex real-world challenges, from autonomous vehicle coordination to swarm robotics and beyond.

I'm passionate about open science and reproducible research. This is why I actively contribute to open-source projects and strive to make my research accessible through well-documented code, comprehensive datasets, and clear publications.

Current Focus

At Meta AI, I'm working on cutting-edge projects involving Large Language Model (LLM) agents for long-horizon tasks. This role allows me to bridge academic research with industrial applications, exploring how advanced AI systems can be deployed at scale.

My PhD research continues to focus on the fundamental challenges of multi-agent coordination, with recent work exploring how Graph Neural Networks can enable more effective communication and learning in heterogeneous agent teams.
